- convert Nodelist and HTMLCollection to real array
Element to locate in the array.
If the index is greater than or equal to array's length, -1 is returned, which means array is not searched.

If the provided index value is a negative number, it is taken as the offset from the end of the array. Note: if provided index is negative, the array is still searched from front to back. If the calculated index is less than 0, then the whole array will be searched. Default: 0 (entire array is searched).
Returns first index of searchElement in array; -1 if not found.

- delete zero or more elements and replace with zero or more elements.

3) Zero or more elements to add

array.splice(start)
array.splice(start, deleteCount)
array.splice(start, deleteCount, item1, item2, ...)
Index at which to start changing the array
If greater than length of array, actual starting index will be set to length of array.
If negative, will begin that many elements from end of array (with origin -1) and will be set to 0 if absolute value is greater than length of array.

An integer indicating the number of old array elements to remove. If deleteCount is 0, no elements are removed. In this case, you should specify at least one new element. If deleteCount is greater than the number of elements left in the array starting at start, then all of the elements through the end of the array will be deleted.
If deleteCount is omitted, or if its value is larger than array.length - start, then all of the elements beginning with start index on through the end of the array will be deleted.
The elements to add to the array, beginning at the start index. If you don't specify any elements, splice() will only remove elements from the array.

reduce((previousValue, currentValue) => { /* … */ } )
reduce((previousValue, currentValue, currentIndex) => { /* … */ } )
reduce((previousValue, currentValue, currentIndex, array) => { /* … */ } )

reduce((previousValue, currentValue) => { /* … */ } , initialValue)
reduce((previousValue, currentValue, currentIndex) => { /* … */ } , initialValue)
reduce((previousValue, currentValue, currentIndex, array) => { /* … */ }, initialValue)
- "reducer" function called with the following arguments:
- value resulting from the previous call to callbackFn. On first call, initialValue if specified, otherwise value of array[0]
- value of current element. On first call, value of array[0] if initialValue was specified, otherwise value of array[1]
- index of currentValue in array. On first call, 0 if initialValue was specified, otherwise 1

- value to which previousValue is initialized the first time callback is called. If initialValue is specified, that also causes currentValue to be initialized to the first value in the array. If initialValue is not specified, previousValue is initialized to first value in the array, and currentValue is initialized to second value in the array.
- value that results from running reducer function to completion over entire array

Preferred way to iterate an array
- invokes a function for each element
Value to use as this (i.e the reference Object) when executing callback
currentValue - value of current element being processed in the array
index - index of current element being processed in the array
array - array that forEach() is being applied to
- forEach is usually not the tool to use with pure functions
(A pure function has no side effects)
- map, filter, and reduce are better tools for pure functions
- use forEach when side effects are necessary -
- referencing outside variables (such as through closure)
Start out using map, filter, reduce
then send output to forEach where side effects are produced in centralized area.
- iterates Array, Map, Set, String, TypedArray, arguments object

- Slightly inefficient because it looks up "length" again with each loop.
Advantage - Doesn't look up "length" with each loop
Preferred syntax for arrays that may contain "falsy" values, such as an empty string or a (numeric) zero.
Use this syntax only for arrays which you know don't contain "falsy" values, such as arrays of objects or DOM nodes.
(The second part of initializing a "for" loop is always a test that tells you when to stop looping.)
When a[i] comes up "falsy" such as "undefined", that causes the loop to stop.
When a[i] comes up "truthy", the loop continues.
With each increment of "i", a value from the array is assigned to "item", in sequential order.
(Note that 3rd component of loop initialization is blank.)
Warning - MDN says "Don't use for arrays"
"for...in should not be used to iterate over an Array where the index order is important."
Advantage - Properties added to Array.prototype are also iterated
- used to merge a list of function arguments into an array

Only the last parameter can be a "rest parameter".
A function's last parameter can be prefixed with ... which takes all remaining arguments and converts them to an array
